revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Charlyne Yi | image = CharlyneYiByPhilKonstantin.jpg | caption = Yi in San Diego, CA, July 2009 | birth_name = Charlyne Amanda Yi | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|1|4}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | occupation = Actress, comedian, musician, writer | years_active = 2006–present }} '''Charlyne Amanda Yi''' (born January 4, 1986)According to the State of California. ''California Birth Index, 1905-1995''. Center for Health Statistics, California Department of Health Services, Sacramento, California. Searchable at http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/39461 is an American actress, comedian, musician and writer. Her performances include music, magic, games, and often audience participation.{{cite news| url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117960233?refCatId=2453| last = Boyd| first = Betsy| title = Charlyne Yi: 10 Comics to Watch| work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]| date = 2007-02-26| accessdate = 2007-04-24}} Her screenwriting debut, the feature film ''[[Paper Heart]]'', won the [[List of Sundance Film Festival award winners|Waldo Salt Screenwriting Award]] at the 2009 [[Sundance Film Festival]]. She is also known for her role as Dr. [[Chi Park]] on the Fox medical drama ''[[House (TV series)|House]]'', the voice of every Ruby on the [[Cartoon Network]] animated series ''[[Steven Universe]]'', the voice of Chloe Park on ''[[We Bare Bears]]'' and the voice of Alice on ''[[Summer Camp Island]]''. ==Early life== Yi was born in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. Her mother, a native of the Philippines, is of [[Filipino people|Filipino]] and [[Spanish people|Spanish]] descent{{citation needed|date=October 2014}}, and her father is of [[Chinese Mexican]], [[Indigenous peoples of Mexico|Native-Mexican]], [[Koreans|Korean]], [[Irish people|Irish]], [[Germans|German]], [[French people|French]], and [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] ancestry.Black, John, [http://www.colormagazineusa.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=257&Itemid=67 "Falling in Love with Charlyne Yi"], ''[[Josefina Bonilla|Color Magazine]]'' USAPrentice, Claire, [http://edinburgh-festivals.com/viewpreview.aspx?id=1343 "Preview: Charlyne Yi - Dances on the Moon"], ''edinburgh-festivals.com'', 3/8/2010 She attended the [[University of California, Riverside]] before leaving to pursue a full-time career in comedy. She had an early interest in performing when she attended [[Bloomington High School (California)|Bloomington High School]] and was involved in theatre. ==Career== [[File:Charlyne Yi at UCB.jpg|thumb|Performing in the [[Garfunkel and Oates]] Christmas Show at the UCB Theater]] Yi began by performing in [[Bloomington, California]]. After high school, she has performed shows in Los Angeles at [[The Steve Allen Theater]], and [[The Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre]]. In 2005 and 2006, she performed in the New York Comedy Festival,{{cite news| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/03/arts/03come.html?ei=5088&en=cb95649bf2ccab44&ex=1288674000&adxnnl=1&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss&adxnnlx=1163187155-nSxp69Qc6Ss0sEIF+4OcEQw | date = 2005-11-03| accessdate = 2007-04-24| last = Keepnews| first = Peter| work = [[The New York Times]]| title = Upstart Comedians Goofing on Andy }} and in 2007 [[HBO]]'s [[U.S. Comedy Arts Festival]] in [[Aspen, Colorado|Aspen]], [[Colorado]]. Yi's film debut was in [[Judd Apatow]]'s 2007 film, ''[[Knocked Up]]''. In 2008, Yi performed as part of the Apatow for Destruction Live comedy show at Montreal's [[Just For Laughs Festival]].{{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=festivals&jump=features&id=3182&articleid=VR1117988754 | work=Variety | title=Just For Laughs highlights | date=2008-07-10}} In the 2009 film ''[[Paper Heart]]'', a "hybrid documentary"{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/film-reviews/film-review-paper-heart-1003934187.story |title=Film Review: Paper Heart |accessdate=2009-03-10 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110055445/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/film-reviews/film-review-paper-heart-1003934187.story |archivedate=January 10, 2010 |df= }} which Yi executive produced in addition to co-writing, she starred as a fictional version of herself, along with [[Michael Cera]]. Yi was chosen as one of ''[[Venus Zine]]''{{'}}s "25 under 25" women for 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.venuszine.com/articles/art_and_culture/5336/25_Under_25 |title=25 under 25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306110639/http://venuszine.com/articles/art_and_culture/5336/25_Under_25 |archive-date=March 6, 2009|date=March 1, 2009|access-date=February 16, 2017|author=Venus Zine Staff|quote=Funny lady Charlyne Yi’s name may not sound familiar, but you have seen her in movies and TV shows like Knocked Up and Miss Guided, and now in Paper Heart, a half-documentary, half-narrative starring Yi’s real-life love interest Michael Cera about the meaning of love. Aww.|work=[[Venus Zine]]}} She has also appeared alongside ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' cast member [[Fred Armisen]] in the music video for the song "Rabbit Habits" by Philadelphia experimental band [[Man Man]]. Yi and [[Paul Rust]] formed the band The Glass Beef. The duo share one electric guitar and both sing lead vocals. In 2006, they released their debut album, ''The Farewell Album'', produced by John Spiker, bassist of [[Tenacious D]]. Yi was featured in the video "Song Away" by [[Hockey (band)|Hockey]].{{cite web |title=Song Away by Hockey with Charlyne Yi |url=http://www.channelapa.com/2009/08/song-away-by-hockey-with-charlyne-yi.html}} She is currently in the band Sacred Destinies. In January 2010, Yi performed a duet about break-up lines (the opposite of pick-up lines) with [[Demetri Martin]] on the episode "2" for the Comedy Central sketch series ''[[Important Things with Demetri Martin]]''. However, the duet was cut from the final edit of the episode.{{fact|date=May 2017}} . She also appeared in Lucifer season 3 episode 25 as the angel of death. From October 2011 to May 2012, Yi starred in [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]'s series ''House'' as Dr. Chi Park, a young doctor with anger-management issues.[http://www.fox.com/house/bios/charlyne-yi.htm "Bio: Charlyne Yi / Dr. Chi Park"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016022834/http://www.fox.com/house/bios/charlyne-yi.htm |date=October 16, 2011 }}, FOX website for the ''House MD'' series{{cite web | url = http://www.channelapa.com/2011/11/charlyne-yi-as-dr-chi-park-on-house.html | title = Charlyne Yi as Dr. Chi Park on House| accessdate = November 9, 2011 | date = November 1, 2011 | publisher = channelAPA.com}} ==Non-profit work== Yi has been involved with [[Oxfam|Oxfam America]] since 2010, working to raise awareness about poverty and hunger around the world.[http://www.oxfamamerica.org/articles/actress-charlyne-yi-fights-hunger-with-oxfam Actress Charlyne Yi fights hunger with Oxfam — Oxfam America] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100921131244/http://www.oxfamamerica.org/articles/actress-charlyne-yi-fights-hunger-with-oxfam |date=September 21, 2010 }} Yi started the non-profit Caring is Cool in 2011, and hosted a benefit show to raise money for the organization.[http://charlyneyi.tumblr.com/post/2750901881/caring-is-cool-is-my-new-non-profit-i-made-to-help Charlyne Yi | Caring is Cool is my new NON-PROFIT I made to help] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717112253/http://charlyneyi.tumblr.com/post/2750901881/caring-is-cool-is-my-new-non-profit-i-made-to-help |date=July 17, 2011 }} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable" |- " ! Year !! Title !! Role !!
